javelin.controller.scenario

Class Scenario

  • java.lang.Object
    • javelin.controller.scenario.Scenario
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Campaign

    public class Scenario
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    Scenario mode is a much faster type of gameplay than the main Campaign mode. It's supposed to be finished on anywhere from 2 hours of play to an afternoon (but of course it can be saved an resumed too). The world is a lot more static in this mode. Several features and Locations are disabled - including RandomEncounters in ohe overworld map and Hazards. The only "moving pieces" in the world map are yourself and Incursions. The FeatureGenerator is disabled after the original world is created, meaning that, wuthout random encounters and other infinite means of gaining experience and loot, you are on a race against time to conquer all hostile Towns - 1 to 3, with varying degress of power according to the quantity in each game. There is only one enemy Realm per game and the starting features are roughly made to be 1/3 neutral and 2/3 hostile.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        public int startingpopulation
        Starting Town population. See statictowns.

      • statictowns

        public boolean statictowns
        If true, Towns will be overidden after World generation according to getscenariochallenge().

      • startingdungeons

        public java.lang.Integer startingdungeons
        If not null, this amount will be seeded during World generation. It will also be the cap as per GenerationData.max. Number of starting dungeons in the World map. Since TempleKeys are important to Winning the game this should be a fair amount, otherwise the player will depend only on Caravans if too many dungeons are destroyed or if unable to find the proper Chest inside the dungeons he does find. Not that dungeons also spawn during the course of a game but since this is highly randomized a late-game player who ran out of dungeons should not be required to depend on that alone.
        See Also:
        Actor.destroy(Incursion), FeatureGenerator

    • Method Detail

      • getscenariochallenge

        public static int getscenariochallenge()
        Returns:
        Starting encounter level for each hostile town in #SCENARIO mode. 20 for 1 hostile town, 15 for 2 or 10 for 3.

      • endday

        public void endday()
        Called at the end of each day. Might be called several times in a row - for example: if a lone Squad decides to rest for a week, it'll be called 7 times in a row.
